title: Uproar forces Lam to suspend policy speech to parliament
text:
But with US lawmakers moving one step close to passing a bill which would abolish trading benefits for Hong Kong if it breaches human rights clauses, there was little in Ms Lam's policy address to appease protesters.

"Despite the stormy times and overwhelming difficulties Hong Kong is experiencing, I believe that so long as we accurately adhere to the principle of one country, two systems, we will be able to get out of the impasse," Ms Lam in her speech, reaffirming her government's commitment to the model which is supposed to preserve the city's independence under Chinese rule until 2047.

“Housing is the toughest livelihood issue facing Hong Kong society. It is also a source of public grievances. I have never taken this matter lightly.”

Ms Lam said more than 1100 people had been injured and more than 2200 arrested since demonstrations over her government's proposed extradition bill first broke out in June. Violence has gripped the city almost every weekend since then, with police using tear gas and rubber bullets against protesters.

Pro-democratic legislators are blocked by security officials as they follow Carrie Lam out of the Legislative Council. AP

The demonstrations have become increasingly violent in the past month. Smaller groups of protesters have vandalised train stations and mainland Chinese banks, and used petrol bombs when confronted by police.

However, on Monday night tens of thousands of people protested peacefully to urge the US government to support proposed laws to protect human rights in the city.

The US House of Representatives passed legislation this week allowing a review of Hong Kong's human rights record to determine whether the territory can still be treated separately from China on trade and other issues. The Senate would still need to pass the legislation and president Donald Trump would have the final say on any action related to Hong Kong.

Advertisement

China's trade war with the US is also hurting Hong Kong's economy, on top of the damage inflicted by more than four months of unrest.

Tourist numbers have plunged, leaving hotels empty and forcing restaurants to close. Even some high-end fashion labels, long a symbol of the city's wealth, are threatening to close their doors.

The first meeting of the city's Legislative Council since the summer recess was also adjourned early. Plans to formally abolish the extradition bill, which would have allowed criminals and suspects in Hong Kong to be sent to mainland China, were deferred until next week.

Ms Lam's package included 10,000 homes for the poor, first home-owner mortgage perks and subsidies for students and low-income families. The government also plans to reclaim more land in the harbour city, which has one of the highest population densities in the world.

However, the package did not address any of the protesters' demands as expected. It was Ms Lam's third policy address in her five-year term.

"We must reverse the prevalent pessimistic sentiments and stop the disorderly behaviour. We have to put aside differences and stop attacking each other, so that we could set sail again based on the values upheld by all," she said.

Bernard Chan, a prominent businessman and politician who has been tipped as a potential successor to Ms Lam, told The Australian Financial Review last month he hoped the policy address would be a circuit-breaker to the protests.
description: Hong Kong’s embattled chief executive was forced to retreat from the city’s parliament and deliver her annual policy address on television after being shouted down by pro-democracy politicians.
